> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/16683?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [b72519e...6042aa4](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/16683?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

@jreback ASV report 
[attached](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/files/1068792/asv_report.txt), indicates that no benchmarks are significantly changed.
@jreback are you OK with the changes here? LGTM on a quick skim.

On the suggestion of @jreback, I have made the test_timedelta unit test cover both 'B' and 'D' frequencies, and have expanded the ASV tests for infer_freq.

Note the unit test in master is actually /wrong/: it asserts that `shifted.freq == index.freq`, which should not hold if index has `freq == 'B'`. This was my original reason for changing freq to 'D' in the test case. I now omit this aspect of the test when `freq == 'B'`, but perform the rest of the test.

The ASV test shows no change in performance when the inferred frequency is daily. There is a 50% slow-down when the inferred frequency is business daily, which is in line with the benchmark I submitted originally with this pull request, and I think is justifiable given the additional checks taking place.

More surprising, perhaps, is that time_infer_freq_none (in my commit; time_infer_freq in master) has a 124% slowdown. However, I think this result is misleading. Note the test case self.no_freq (in master: self.a) actually triggers the bug this PR request solves! So in master, it will wrongly return an inferred frequency of business daily, short-circuiting the tests. By contrast, in this branch it must go both through the whole of _is_business_daily (since it passes the initial 'quick check' on day deltas), and _get_wom_rule. It is therefore a worst case example for this branch, and does 'better than it should' (because of the bug) in master.
looks like a tiny lint error.
